briefOverview: Creation is completed, the Sabbath is blessed, and humanity is placed in Eden with commandments, stewardship, and companionship established.
summary: God finishes creation, blesses and sanctifies the seventh day, and declares the works good. He explains that all things were created spiritually before they appeared naturally; then man is formed from the dust, given the breath of life, and placed in Eden. God causes trees to grow, including the tree of life and the tree of the knowledge of good and evil, and describes the river from Eden dividing into four named heads. The man is commissioned to dress and keep the garden and is commanded not to eat from the tree of knowledge, with a clear warning yet allowance of choice. Seeing that it is not good for man to be alone, God brings animals for naming but then forms the woman from the man’s rib; Adam recognizes their shared nature, establishing the pattern of marriage as becoming one flesh, and the pair are unashamed in their nakedness.
externalContext: This chapter comes from the Book of Moses in the Pearl of Great Price, a Latter-day Saint scripture derived from Joseph Smith’s early 1830s revision of Genesis (the Joseph Smith Translation). The narrative adopts a first-person divine voice and introduces distinct Latter-day Saint emphases such as spiritual creation prior to physical creation and explicit human agency. The Pearl of Great Price was first published in 1851 and canonized by The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in 1880. References to rivers and lands (Pishon, Gihon, Hiddekel/Tigris, Euphrates; Havilah; Ethiopia/Cush; Assyria) reflect the broader ancient Near Eastern setting associated with biblical Eden geography.
externalReferences: The chapter closely parallels Genesis 2:1–25, including the sanctification of the seventh day, the garden in Eden, the prohibition regarding the tree of knowledge, and the creation of woman from the man. The Sabbath theme later grounds Israel’s weekly observance (Exodus 20:8–11). The declaration about marriage and becoming “one flesh” is cited by Jesus in discussions of marriage and divorce (Matthew 19:4–6) and by Paul regarding Christ and the church (Ephesians 5:31–32). The tree of life reappears in later biblical texts as a symbol of divine life and healing (Genesis 3:22–24; Revelation 22:2).

sectionTitles.title: Formation of man and Eden’s charge
Creation of woman and one flesh

practicalQuestions: How might I honor the Sabbath as a day God blesses and sets apart?
What does it mean in practice to exercise stewardship over creation entrusted to me?
In what ways do I exercise agency responsibly when God’s commands and my choices intersect?
How can I cultivate companionship and mutual support in marriage or close partnerships?
What boundaries or warnings in my life require respect even when I am free to choose?
uncertainAreas: The precise meaning of “spiritually” created things before their natural appearance is not fully defined in the text. The statement that man became “the first flesh upon the earth” raises interpretive questions about sequence and scope. The phrase “in the day thou eatest thereof thou shalt surely die” could refer to immediate spiritual death or eventual mortality. The geographical identifications of Eden’s rivers and lands (Havilah, Ethiopia/Cush, Assyria) remain debated.
